Data on IBD hospitalizations come from the OECD (King 2019), which provides rates for primary discharges spanning 2000–2015. In 2015, the hospitalization rate for IBD was 41.0/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 29.3/100,000 in 2000 (AAPC: −2.38; 95% CI: −2.55, −2.00). Coward 2020 provides results for both primary and secondary discharges for IBD in the province of Alberta spanning 2002–2015. In 2015, the primary hospitalization rate for IBD in Alberta was 22.59/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 40.31/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: −3.40; 95% CI: −3.98, −2.81). In 2015, the secondary hospitalization rate for IBD in Alberta was 57.89/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 83.88/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: −1.98; 95% CI: −2.42, −1.49).

Data on CD hospitalizations come from Coward 2020, which provides rates for primary and secondary discharges in the province of Alberta spanning 2002–2015. In 2015, the hospitalization rate for primary CD discharges was 12.99/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 28.20/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: −4.62; 95% CI: −5.21, −4.03). In 2015, the hospitalization rate for secondary CD discharges was 38.94/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 60.29/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: −2.32; 95% CI: −2.84, −1.79). (See also Nabalamba 2004 and Rahman 2019).

Data on UC hospitalizations come from Coward 2020, which provides rates for primary and secondary discharges in the province of Alberta spanning 2002–2015. In 2015, the hospitalization rate for primary UC discharges was 8.96/100,000, which had not significantly decreased from 11.12/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: −0.74; 95% CI: −1.81, 0.34). In 2015, the hospitalization rate for secondary CD discharges was 17.44/100,000, which had not significantly decreased from 20.49/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: −0.66; 95% CI: −1.36, 0.05). (See also Nabalamba 2004 and Kaplan 2012).

Data on IBD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002–2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for IBD in Alberta was 21.81/100,000, which was significantly lower than 38.18/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -3.01; 95% CI: -3.38, -2.64). In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for IBD was 142.18/100,000 which significantly increased from 110.65/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: 1.56; 95% CI: -1.36, 0.33) (Buie 2022).

Data on CD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002–2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for CD in Alberta was 12.46/100,000, which was significantly lower than 26.09/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -4.12; 95% CI: -4.48, -3.76). In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for CD was 73.11/100,000 which had increased significantly from 72.18/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: 0.42; 95% CI: 0.11, 0.72) (Buie 2022).

Data on UC hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002–2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for UC in Alberta was 8.87/100,000, which was not significantly lower than 11.04/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -0.73; 95% CI: -1.48, 0.02). In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for UC was 51.27/100,000 which significantly increased from 28.71/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: 3.29; 95% CI: 2.94, 3.63) (Buie 2022).

National:
Data on IBD hospitalizations come from 19 studies using estimated national data and spanning 2000–2018 [other data available from 1990]. Only five of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. According to King 2019, in 2010, the hospitalization rate for unspecified discharge types was 33.9/100,000, which had significantly increased from 25.8/100,000 in 2000 (AAPC: 2.40; 95% CI: 1.50, 5.31). Conversely, Galoosian 2009 had a (not significantly) decreasing trend for primary IBD discharges, falling from 50.28/100,000 in 2007 to 48.39/100,000 in 2013 (AAPC: −0.64; 95% CI: −1.75, 0.49). See also Ananthakrishnan 2008, Ananthakrishnan 2011b, Barber 2018, Barnes 2016, Beery 2018, Cohen-Mekelburg 2018, Dahiya 2021, Dalal 2019, Ding 2021, Nguyen 2010, Peery 2019, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Rezapour 2018, Sonnenberg 2009a, Sonnenberg 2009b, Sridhar 2011, Ma 2020.

Data on CD hospitalizations come from 26 studies using estimated national data and spanning 2000–2018 [other data available from 1990]. Only eight of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. Almost all studies display a significantly increasing trend for UC hospitalizations. According to Malarcher 2017, in 2013, the hospitalization rate for primary discharges was 19.07/100,000, which had significantly increased from 18.5/100,000 in 2003 (AAPC: 0.90; 95% CI: 0.12, 1.69). In 2013 the hospitalization rate for secondary discharges was 59.7/100,000, which had significantly increased from 44.2/100,000 in 2003 (AAPC: 3.65; 95% CI: 2.79, 4.51). Conversely, Galoosian 2009 had a (not significantly) decreasing trend for primary CD discharges, falling from 39.34/100,000 in 2007 to 37.06/100,000 in 2013 (AAPC: −0.99; 95% CI: −2.20, 0.24). See also Ananthakrishnan 2011a, Barber 2018, Barnes 2016, Beery 2018, Bewtra 2007, Dalal 2019, Kichloo 2021, Limketkai 2017, Lowe 2021, Ma 2020, Rezapour 2018, Nguyen 2007, Nguyen 2010, Peery 2019, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Schwartz 2020, Sharma 2017, Sonnenberg 2009a, Sonnenberg 2009b, Sridhar 2011, Stein 2016, Uwagbale 2021, Wadhwa 2016, Xu 2019.

Data on UC hospitalizations come from 25 studies using estimated national data and spanning 2000–2018 [other data available from 1990]. Only nine of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. According to Sharma 2017, in 2012, the hospitalization rate for secondary discharges was 33.22/100,000, which had significantly increased from 27.94/100,000 in 2004 (AAPC: 3.73; 95% CI: 2.17, 5.32). See also Ananthakrishnan 2010, Ananthakrishnan 2011a, Barber 2018, Barnes 2016, Beery 2018, Bewtra 2007, Galoosian 2009, Geltzeiler 2014, Kichloo 2021, Lowe 2021, Ma 2020, Nguyen 2007, Nguyen 2010, Olaiya 2021, Peery 2019, Poojary 2017, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Rezapour 2018, Schwartz 2020, Sonnenberg 2009a, Sonnenberg 2009b, Sridhar 2011.

Data on IBD hospitalizations come from 19 studies using estimated national data and spanning 1998–2018. A subset of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. A recent study showed the primary discharge rate to increase significantly from 27.05/100,000 in 2005, to 29.71/100,000 in 2016 (AAPC: 0.68; 95% CI: 0.06, 1.31) (Ma 2020). Additionally, according to Sonnenberg 2009, all cause hospitalization for IBD signifcantly increased from 59.47/100,000 in 2000, to 76.24/100,000 in 2006 (AAPC: 4.39; 95% CI: 3.48, 5.31).

Data on CD hospitalizations come from 29 studies using estimated national data and spanning 1990–2018. A subset of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. Lowe et al. 2021 found that the hospitalization rate for all-cause discharges was 44.11/100,000 in 2017, which had significantly increased from 40.82/100,000 in 2010 (AAPC: 1.12; 95% CI: 0.93, 1.31).
